selected_quotes: A majority (76.7%) of individuals who had a knee surgery in college did develop OA
Meniscus is key to joint health #ATAF

citation.abstract:
Individuals who sustain a knee surgery have been shown to have an increased likelihood to develop osteoarthritis.
Identify the consequences of knee surgery in a cohort of former collegiate athletes.
Cross-sectional.
Research laboratory.
A group of 100 former Division I collegiate athletes aged 40-65 (60 Males, 40 Females) participated in the study.
All individuals self-reported whether they sustained a knee injury during college requiring surgery and if they have been diagnosed with knee osteoarthritis (OA) by a medical physician post knee injury. Individuals were categorized into three groups: no history of knee injury requiring surgery (33 Males, 24 Females, 54.53±5.95years), history of knee surgery in college with no diagnosis of OA later in life (4 Males, 6 Females, 51.26±7.29years), and history of knee surgery in college with physician diagnosed OA later in life (23 Males, 10 Females, 54.21±7.64years). All individuals completed the Knee Injury and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (KOOS) and SF-36v2.
Scores on the KOOS and SF-36v2.
A majority (76.7%) of individuals who had a knee surgery in college did develop OA. The largest differences were on the KOOS scales between the healthy knee and surgical knee/OA groups with the surgical knee/OA group scoring worse on the KOOS. The largest mean differences between those groups were seen on the KOOS-quality of life scale (mean difference: 49.76; Χ(2)(3)=44.65; p=0.0001) and KOOS-sports scale (mean difference: 43.69; Χ (2) (3)=28.69; p=0.0001. Additionally, scores on the SF-36v2 physical component scale was significantly worse for the surgical knee surgery/knee OA group, compared to the healthy knee group and the surgical knee only group (p<0.007).
Later in life functional limitations were observed in individuals who sustained a knee injury requiring surgery and developed OA. These findings support increased efforts toward prevention of knee injuries and consideration of the long-term implication when making treatment and return to activity decisions.
citation.title: The Long Term Impact of Osteoarthritis Following Knee Surgery in Former Collegiate Athletes
